ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about microeconomics, while learning a bit about stocks and investing for the future. I also realized the impact that economics has on various aspects of society, such as simple decision making.
I learned a lot about the basic of microeconomics. Involves graphs, vocab, algebra, some stocks
learned about microeconomics and how it describes behaviors of people in everyday life
I gained an understanding of the labor and capital markets, as well as other basic microeconomic processes and structures.
I learned a lot about how to study more effectively and learn to apply concepts as opposed to merely memorizing concepts.
I developed the skill of learning in a bigger classroom and staying on task.
I learned the basics of microeconomics, as well as some other topics, like behavioral economics and game theory.

demand/ supply/ Price elasticity/ opportunity cost substitutes/ complements/ indifference curve/ intertempotral choice budget constrain/ tax/ income & substation effects Monopoly/ oligopoly/ perfect competition/ externalities Market failures/ costs, profits, prices, revenue and firms labor market/ capital market/ interest rates a firm in long run/ short run/ public goods
I learned a lot about Econ.

I definitwly feel more confident in my ability to understand fundamental microecon questions and make decisions as a more educated consumer. It also made me feel more capable of taking future economic courses.
I had never taken an Econ class before so exposure to the subject/learning concepts.
I learned basic microeconomics and how it applies to some current events.
I learned to think like an economist and make decisions more effectively through a study of subjects like indifference curves, equilibria, etc.
Quantitative skills

I learned, as the course name suggests, a basic introduction to economic concepts and thinking. Having never taken an economics course before, I found this class to provide a good grounding in graphical analysis and the vocabulary of economics.
introductory microeconomics!
I learned essential skills of basic economic knowledge.
I developed a lot of the core skills needed to continue studying microeconomics.
It helped to provide a baseline example of what microeconomics focus on and was a decent first course to take.
A much greater understanding of certain economic theories and models, and how they can apply to real life situations.
I learned that Yale's introductory microeconomics class was in fact not introductory and catered mainly toward those who had prior experience in economics.

Firm behavior in a perfectly competitive, imperfectly competitive, and monopolistic market as well as some Game Theory and consumer behavior. Supply and Demand, elasticity, and generally am now more able to at least give a very basic explanation for why the market appears the way it does.
I gained a basic level of understanding of microeconomics.
i learned how to teach myself concepts i didnt understand and a great foundation of microeconomics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The fact that the note slides were posted was very helpful.
It wasn't a bad course, but I'm just not that interested in microeconomics.
the pace of the class was really fast, so it's hard to retain a lot of the information. the psets and professor were helpful in helping me understand the material

I think the course would benefit from explaining the mathematical concepts behind certain microeconomic concepts better (marginal rate of substitution and derivative for instance), rather than trying to maneuver around the math.
The class as a whole was great, however, I feel the implementation of a practice test or two would be extremely helpful.
A strength is the help that is offered. A weakness is having entire grade made up of homework and exams - it became a bit stressful.
There could be practice problems for exams.

The buzz groups were definitely very helpful. As someone expecting a seminar, I was still happy with the lecture-style teaching and learned a lot from it (the lectures were well done and the content was fairly well presented). I would only point out, as a weakness of the course, that students who aren't well versed in economics and/or pick it up more slowly find it harder to understand the content quickly and follow along with the lessons as they build on "learned" content.

Strengths: my instructor meant well Weaknesses: the class was a false seminar. Office hours limited (one day a week tiny room most of the time not enough room for everyone). Lecture style but no lecture safety nets I.e. sections or TAs. Limited material given to practice. Was especially challenging for those who were never exposed to subject prior to college.
I like the straight forward and easy to follow structure. It could have been more engaging but Im not sure if that would have benefited the class.
Lectures were very slideshow-based and went by very quickly.

Strengths: Solid textbook, Straightforward exams, Prof. Simmons is very pleasant Weaknesses: Poorly written and confusing p-sets (the grading scheme was very particular to wording, not based on comprehension of the concepts), Unhelpful peer tutoring office hours (the hours were entirely based on solving - or simply giving out answers for - the p-sets), Lectures slides are inconsistent and are not self-explanatory (the professor's explanations are often confusing as well).
strengths pretty informative Weaknesses instructor poor, unorganized
It is well structured and I like the flow of the course.

The course requires a lot of engagement with your classmates, which is good. I also think that Prof. Simons has a very good lecturing style. One thing that I would improve about the course is a more spread-out office hours schedule. Prof. Simons' and our TF's hours were on back-to-back days, and it would be nice if they were more spread out.
Strengths: Professor Simons and her depth of knowledge and enthusiasm for economics. Weaknesses: although advertised as a seminar, the class is really taught more like a small lecture.

Strengths: reasonable amount of work, Simons explains concepts well in lecture, and seminar style makes it more approachable and easier to ask questions. Weaknesses: content can be really tricky and has a lot of nuances, and the "seminar" title in the class is a bit misleading, because it was more like a smaller lecture than a seminar.

I found it pretty difficult to learn well in this class, if Im being honest. The slides were often rushed through in class and many of the examples we did in class werent on the slides so it was more difficult to study them later on. In addition, peer tutoring/office hours were incredibly unhelpful. By a few weeks into the semester, you just went to office hours to hear the answers to the PSETS. Another thing I found frustrating was that the professor/grader didnt seem to care whether or not you actually understood a concept, as much as they cared that you wrote the exact right answer. Overall, despite the fact that it was a seminar I didnt feel that it was an environment especially conducive to learning.
This course was not well taught. I learned far more from the textbook than I did in class.
strength is manageable work load. Weakness is not enough examples used to teach material

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. I learned a good amount while the workload was very manageable. The professor and TA were both very accessible and helpful.
Yes, but be aware that you should study for the exams and go to office hours. It's a good course to understand the world a little more and get a QR credit along the way.
take this course if you really have an interest in micro, otherwise the material might feel dry
Not really, I was not very interested in the material.
Yes, professor Simmons was amazing at explaining all the concepts and made sure to apply the concepts as opposed to merely stating them.
yes, it is a good class to increase your basic econ understanding.
Yes for people who needs microeconomics as their prerequisite.
Yes because it's more personal
Yes; I definitely would pick this seminar-style again over the larger lecture, and I had no qualms with the Professor. She knows what she's doing and teaches well.

No the structure of the course meant a lot of it is self taught with limited resources for guidance. This is especially challenging if you dont have a strong school background to begin with i.e. I graduated from an underfunded public school.
Yes I think this is an important thing for most students to know.
Yes if you 'd like a solid foundation to microeconomic theory.
Yes it was a good starter course in econ

Many students take this course without intending on pursuing a degree in economics. To those students, I would recommend an Econ elective (Ex. Health Economics). Introduction to Microeconomics does not provide any particularly exciting concepts, nor does it do a great job at teaching students to think like an economist. The course serves its purpose as an entrance to the Yale Economics track, however it is not a particularly enriching 4th/5th credit for non-majors. *all that being said, prospective majors have no fear. Economics spans far beyond the realm of introductory micro and the concepts outlined in this course will be very useful in future courses.
would not take the lecture!
Yes
100 percent. If you want to study econ, this course is a must. Even if you don't, it's a generally interesting course that you can keep up with pretty easily.
Yes, but only to a student who has a strong conceptual foundation in math and/or has already taken economics.

I would recommend the course. I learned a lot about econ and really enjoyed Simons' classes. Compared to my friends who took 115, I believe 110 was much better, specifically in its environment and course structure.

I definitely would not. There are so many great classes here at Yale that taking this class would be a waste of a student's time worrying and stressing about a poorly taught course like this. Misleading in its title, this was not an introductory course but rathe expected the students to teach themselves such novel material. This was one of the most disengaging courses here at Yale despite my efforts to constantly feel excited about the class material and learning. This class can be pinpointed as one of the reasons why Economics major has such a terrible reputation. It perfectly embodies the "Econ Snake" image where no one in the class is willing to help each other or talk in general to avoid receiving any suspicions of them struggling. However if intro-micro is indeed as prerequisite for your major, take this course with another professor not with Simons.

If you are considering majoring in Econ, I would say youd probably still learn more in this class than you would in the lecture. But it was not incredibly stimulating or well taught, so if you dont need it for any reason, Im not sure I would highly recommend taking this course.
I would never recommend this course to anyone. It was poorly taught, there was no framework to help students to reinforce understanding, and I really felt let down by this course.
Only if you need to take economics. Do the lecture instead
